prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We want to trace the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas in a sample of 10 LIRGs. The 0".2 resolution corresponds to 100-200 pc at the distances of our sample. This scale well matches the scale of star-forming regions in LIRGs and will allow to accurately estimate the gas surface density. Based on previous observations of LIRGs, we expect CO 2-1 brightness temperatures not lower than 20 K, and 3 K for CS 5-4. The goal sensitivity of 0.6 K will allow to reach a snr of at least 40 for CO 2-1 and 5 for CS 5-4. The spectral resolution of 50 km/s suits well the expected line widths of several 100 km/s. We choose to observe 4 spw, covering a wide range in velocities around the CO and CS lines in order to allow for errors in redshift and to be able to detect high-velocity winds. Most galaxies will require a single pointing, while we choose to observe a mosaic of 2 pointings in the pair UGC02369 in order to detect both nuclei.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A major goal of future large observational facilities (SKA, JWST) will be to use high-z objects to trace the history of star formation and galaxy evolution in the Universe. Local LIRGs offer the unique opportunity to study in detail extreme star-formation and starburst/AGN feedback processes, which will be essential to understand observations of higher-z galaxies. While a number of famous local LIRGs have been studied extensively at multiple wavebands, it is unclear whether these few sources are typical of the local LIRG population. We propose to observe 1~mm molecular emission in a small but representative sample of LIRGs, which has already been granted observing time with HST, Spitzer, Galex, Chandra, and eMERLIN. ALMA will add crucial information about the molecular gas surface density and kinematics, which is needed to constrain models of star formation and starburst/AGN feedback in LIRGs near and far.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Virginia, University of
Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Institute of Cosmos Science (ICC), University of Barcelona
